metadata.case_name: Defendants 8 to 11 v. Respondents Nos. 1 to 3

facts.text: Dispute relates to land measuring 179 kanals and 2 marlas, situate in village Wanderjatana.
On August 26, 1949, defendants 3 to 7 sold the said land to defendants 1 and 2 for a consideration of Rs. 37,611.
The sale deed was registered on February 15, 1950.
On August 26, 1950, defendants 8 to 11 instituted Suit No. 231 of 1950 in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, II Class, Faridkot, to pre-empt the said sale.

On January 6, 1951, the vendees (defendants 1 and 2) and defendants 8 to 11 entered into a compromise. Vendees admitted receipt of Rs. 1,700; balance Rs. 35,911 to be paid by April 27, 1951, for possession through court.
Compromise deed filed in Court of District Judge; decree dated January 23, 1951, providing for dismissal if balance not paid by April 27, 1951.
Defendants 8 to 11 deposited Rs. 35,911 on April 23, 1951.
Defendants 8 to 11 got possession of the land on May 17, 1951.

Before April 23, 1951, respondents (claiming owners of land in same patti) filed Suit No. 13 of 1951 in Court of Subordinate Judge, II Class, Faridkot, to enforce right of pre-emption. Original vendors as d3-7, vendees d1-2, prior plaintiffs d8-11.
Subordinate Judge dismissed suit 13/1951, finding defendants 8-11 had become vendees through court decree before suit.
Additional District Judge, Faridkot, in Civil Appeal No. 10/1952, held plaintiffs and d8-11 equal rights, entitled to share 3/7 and 4/7 proportionately.
High Court in R.S.A. Nos. 57 and 130 of 1952 upheld sharing but remanded to District Judge on: (1) amount paid by d8-11 and good faith; (2) s.17C cl. e applicability.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellants (defendants 8-11), having obtained compromise decree, deposited money, and taken possession, defeated respondents' (equal pre-emptors) right to share under s.17 Punjab Pre-emption Act.
Applicability of s.28 Punjab Pre-emption Act requiring suits pending together for sharing.
Whether doctrine of lis pendens applies to substitution of appellants pendente lite.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 28 indicates property divided between equal pre-emptors only when both suits pending at time of decree.
Appellants exercised pre-emption right by obtaining decree or depositing money, substituted in place of original vendees; respondents need superior right.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: General law of pre-emption; right of substitution

respondent_arguments.text: Equal pre-emptors have statutory right under s.17 to share land; appellants substituted pendente lite, hit by lis pendens, cannot claim higher rights than original vendees.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 17 Punjab Pre-emption Act; doctrine of lis pendens

court_reasoning.text: Right of pre-emption is primary right to offer, secondary remedial right of substitution for whole property, not share; preference essence, must be superior to vendee/substitute.
court_reasoning.key_observation: General law does not recognize sharing among rival claimants.

court_reasoning.text: Punjab Pre-emption Act does not enlarge right; s.13 allows joint/several exercise of whole right; s.17 applies only where right yet to be exercised and equals found.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants ceased to be pre-emptors upon substitution.

court_reasoning.text: S.28 procedural for joining suits, does not affect substantive rights; no bar if one suit decreed first.

Lis pendens applies to pre-emption suits but not to transfer recognizing subsisting pre-existing right; appellants' right subsisting (suit filed, decreed, complied timely before respondents' suit completion).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants acquired indefeasible right upon deposit and possession.

court_reasoning.text: Compromise decree conditional; substitution only upon fulfillment and possession, not earlier.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pre-emptor not owner until conditions met.

holdings.text: Appellants obtained indefeasible title to whole land upon depositing amount and taking possession pursuant to decree, as their pre-emptive right was subsisting and not hit by lis pendens.
S.17 inapplicable where one pre-emptor has already exercised right via decree and substitution.
Doctrine of lis pendens does not apply to substitution enforcing subsisting pre-emptive right.

precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of pre-emption as jus ad rem, primary and secondary rights.
Secondary right as substitution in shoes of vendee.
No right to share; whole property; s.17 inapplicable post-exercise; lis pendens exception.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mt. Sant Kaur v. Teja Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Lis pendens exception for subsisting pre-emptive right; barred right treated as non-existent.
Lis pendens applies if right barred.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wazir Ali Khan v. Zahir Ahmad Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Lis pendens only if not recognizing subsisting right.

precedents_cited.case_name: Deonandan Prashad Singh v. Ramdhari Chowdhri
precedents_cited.relevance: Substitution only upon payment and possession under decree.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Pre-emption Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines right, procedure for exercise, sharing only pre-exercise among equals, joining suits; does not enlarge incidents of right.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, holding that appellants (defendants 8-11) had perfected their pre-emptive right through timely suit, compromise decree, deposit, and possession, acquiring indefeasible title to the whole land; respondents' equal right defeated without superior claim or applicability of lis pendens or s.17 sharing.
outcome.relief_granted: Appellants upheld as entitled to entire property; respondents' suit defeated.

key_quotes.text: "The right of pre-emption is not a right to the thing sold but a right to the offer of a thing about to be sold."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is a right of substitution but not of re-purchase, i.e., the pre-emptor takes the entire bargain and steps into the shoes of the original vendee."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Preference being the essence of the right, the plaintiff must have a superior right to that of the vendee or the person substituted in his place."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The appellants acquired an indefeasible right to the suit land, at any rate, when they took possession of the land pursuant to the terms of the decree."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Final holding on perfection of right.
